Award.AwardTitle: International Collaboration in Chemistry: Dynamic Nuclear Polarization by Nanoparticles and Clusters
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program and the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Michael Bowman of the Department of Chemistry at The University of Alabama will develop new classes of reagents to increase the sensitivity of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and make it possible to image specific chemicals and proteins. The goal of this research is to exploit the properties of free radicals and clusters of free radicals to develop ways of enhancing the MRI signals from specific molecules using non-toxic, earth-abundant materials so that the transport and fate of those molecules can be studied. This project is part of an international collaboration with chemists in Novosibirsk, Russia and provides an excellent opportunity for introducing under-represented students in the University of Alabama's Chemistry and Research Experience for Undergraduate program to the global science, technology, engineering and math career opportunities of today's economy through planned outreach activities.

Free radicals and biradicals are used in a process known as dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) to greatly enhance nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and MRI signals for molecular imaging and the study of rare molecules and intermediates. The use of DNP is hindered by its high cost and limited performance. Improvements to DNP will be made by the synthesis of much better polarizing agents based on a detailed understanding of the DNP process and the role of the electron spin dynamics of the free radicals that drive DNP. This project involves an international collaboration coupling: 1) experimental studies of free radical spin dynamics and DNP; with 2) theoretical modeling of the role of free radicals in DNP; to 3) guide the synthesis of new free radicals and poly-radicals aimed at improving the practical performance of DNP.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the dynamics of electron spins that are used to enhance MRI images through a process known as dissolution DNP.  Energy that is poured into the electron spins of molecules known as trityls becomes transfered to the spins of atoms in other molecules, greatly enhancing their magnetic resonance signals. This method promises to revolutionize molecular imaging by making it possible to map out and study the distribution of various kinds of molecules in active chemical, biological and physical systems. The efficiency of converting the input energy into signal enhancement is poorly understood and needs significant improvement. Electron spins receive energy at the start of the DNP process and their dynamics in dissipating versus transfering that energy on is a key step at the beginning of the DNP process.

This project was an international collaboration that paired the expertise in measuring and understanding electron spin dynamics at the University of Alabama with the expertise in design and synthesis of trityl molecules in Russia. This synergistic pairing led to breakthroughs in both the understanding of how trityls function in DNP and in development of a wide range of trityls with new molecular properties for use in DNP, molecular imaging, and as molecular probes and labels. It also provided undergraduate and graduate students with experience and training to compete in science and technology on the global market. The significant highlights include:

  1. It is custers of trityls and not individual trityl molecules that dominates and controls the flux of energy into the electron spin system. As a result, the molecular properties of trityls that influence their behavior in solution are key factors for optimizing dissolution DNP, and help explain the scatter in DNP efficiencies reported by different labs.
  2. Individual trityl molecules that are not in clusters are dominant for energy transfer among spins and are a key link in signal enhancement.
  3. The clusters important in DNP are as small as 2-3 molecules in close physical contact with each other. The close contact allows the electron spins to interact and acquire new properties.
  4. Flexible and high-yield synthetic routes, like that shown in the figure, were developed. This resulted in trityls with a much wider array of physical and molecular properties, extending the range of possible systems where dissolution DNP could be employed. The new synthetic routes also made possible the synthesis of a number of linked dimers, trimers and tetramers for testing the molecular and spin dynamic properties of trityls in DNP.
  5. The newly developed trityl synthesis broadened the use of trityls as molecular probes and labels for biochemical, materials and soft matter studies.
  6. This project also provided valuable opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to gain significant research experience, to present their work to their peers and to the scientific community and to attend regional, national and  international scientific meetings and advanced workshops. Among these students are members of four groups under-represented in the technical STEM disciplines who decided, partially as a result of this experience, to enter graduate or professional school in a STEM field.
